In the meantime, it’s worth spotlighting the corruption. This is a switcheroo to replace the clean energy electrons from Revolution with polluting fossil-fuel-generated electrons, adding revenues to Trump’s political patrons and string-pullers.
That moves us to litigation, where my experience tells me the discovery phase will be fascinating as the lawyers dig into the true motivations and scheming behind this ugly fossil-fuel thuggery.

The far right is undeniably twitchy, because the participants know the Scheme better than anyone. The points Jackson has made so far about patterns and preferences and predisposition likely only touch the surface of a far deeper problem.

If the Emperor has no clothes, and chooses to walk down the Main Street of the city, it may very well be indecorous to call him out as buck naked. But the real wrong in that scenario is in the naked parade down Main Street, not in the call that points the nakedness out.
To rely on another’s “collegiality” to hide one’s own mischief isn’t fair play.

If it would be unseemly for a gentleman or gentlelady to call out a colleague for having their hand, or their friends’ hands, in the gentleman’s or gentlelady’s pocket, is it not worse to have put that hand in the pocket in the first place?

Jackson may have come to the Court sharing those obvious concerns. If so, she had a running start on noticing the mischief. She may choose not to look at the Men in Black Neuralyzer and disappear the awareness she brought of the mischief at the Court. Nor should she.
Their discretion, decorum and “collegiality” have limits — and should have limits. Truth and candor are also judicial virtues.
KBJ comes from the district and circuit courts, where many judges are concerned about the mischief surrounding the Supreme Court. It’s happening in plain view. Judges are not idiots.

What if a colleague uses your “collegiality” as a strategic tactic, like a pick on a basketball court, deliberately for advantage? Surely, the coin of collegiality has a flip-side obligation to behave in such a way that your colleague’s collegiality is never abused.
She has begun looking at interests, and motives, and connections. She’s begun to point behind the curtain at what “collegiality” obscures.
Justice Jackson has begun looking at patterns, and noticing what types of parties tend to win, and which tend to lose. She has noticed procedural discrepancies.

These are all unseemly things to discuss, indecorous, and not at all “collegial.” But if they are true, should they not be discussed? How much mischief happening in plain view in the courthouse should a justice ignore in the interest of “collegiality”?

What if flotillas of secretly-funded amici curiae appear before the Court and sing in conspicuous harmony, and win with conspicuous frequency, and the Court makes little to no effort to enforce its own rules about amicus disclosure about their financing and coordination?

What if we are in a time when novel judicial doctrines, reverse-engineered for happy results for certain special interests, are grown and fertilized in special-interest-funded legal hothouses and then make their way through the Court to become the law of the land?

What if we are in a time when favored parties and litigants win victories with statistically astounding regularity? And justices are feted at organizational fund-raising dinners where those statistically-astounding winners convene?
And sheltered behind the weakest ethics review of any court in the land whenever the gifts program is challenged?
What if we are in a time when a billionaires’ gifts program has given certain justices ‘lifestyles of the rich and famous’ and they have reciprocated with favorable rulings?

What if we are in a time when a billionaire-funded scheme has spent decades trying to pack the Court with billionaire-agreeable justices, so as to “capture” the Court in the sense of “regulatory capture” or “agency capture” — and what if the billionaires have finally succeeded?
But what if we’re not in ordinary times?

All of which is well and good — in ordinary times. It’s akin to members of Congress calling each other “the distinguished gentleman” or the “distinguished gentlelady,” to maintain decorum and avoid events like the caning of Senator Sumner.
Second, issues come and issues go, and an ally in one case is an opponent in another. Third, the Court thinks of itself as a stately institution, hence decorum matters.
One of the internal traditions of the Court is “collegiality.” First, you’re there for life, so you may as well get along.

What's up with Justice Jackson? She started making her mark and speaking out early, and some of her dissents are so pointed Kagan and Sotomayor don’t even join them. The far right is out for her, and even Republican justices are getting snarky.

6.  Reduce Corporate Political Influence. America’s fifty-year experiment with corporate influence in our democracy, contrary to the plain wisdom of the Founders, has proven to be a dangerous failure. Out they go; back to government by the people.

When it does, and suffering is widespread, people will care how we got there. We got there because for decades the fossil fuel industry ran, and the Republican Party aided and abetted, the biggest campaign of lies, corruption and disinformation in human history.

As Hemingway said about bankruptcies, economic collapses happen “gradually, then all at once.” Look at insurance in Florida, Louisiana and California and you see that we are well into “gradually”; it’s hard to predict what triggers “all at once,” but it’s coming.

Insurance collapse hits mortgage markets, which hits property values, which can lead to general economic collapse. The Fed Chair just warned that in 10-15 years, regions of the U.S. won’t have mortgages. A $25 trillion real estate hit is predicted globally.

Home insurance is the forerunner of climate’s economic consequences. Insurance can’t assess risk in an imaginary future, it has to assess risk in the real world. The insurance business model looking forward is colliding with the fossil fuel industry’s lies.

Nature, however, doesn’t care about human lies, corruption or political quid pro quos. She operates by God-given immutable laws of nature that we call physics, chemistry, and biology. So despite the lies, long-predicted dangers are now coming to pass.

With Trump re-elected, the payback to fossil fuel for its financial support is in full view, unashamedly pretending that climate change is a “hoax,” and that electricity from solar and wind is not “energy.” Decades of lies and corruption were rewarded.

The link between Court capture and climate denial was crystal clear, with Trump’s counsel bragging that Court capture and deregulation (i.e. pollution regs) were for them “two sides of the same coin.” That coin was in the polluters’ pocket.

When Trump was elected, Court capture went into overdrive, with every indication of a deal between Kochs and Trump to hand them Supreme Court (and energy and environment) appointments in return for an end to Koch attacks on Trump.

Traditional lobbying groups, like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and National Association of Manufacturers, learned to actively participate in the climate denial operation (likely for big money) or at least stand back and not challenge the lies.

The scheme took decades to come to full fruition, with a support network of doctrine factories, “amicus” front groups, fake science, and billionaire donors to reward amenable justices — a full judicial-influence ecosystem, much overlapped with climate denial.

A covert scheme was also launched to capture and control the Supreme Court, with hundreds of millions more dollars. That seems like a lot, but the payback has been in the tens of billions, particularly for polluters protecting a $700B pollute-for-free subsidy.

Republicans got a clear signal: you’re in with fossil fuel, or you’re out of the party. (Ask Bob Inglis.) Devilishly clever, that let fossil fuel brand climate change as a partisan issue, not just self-serving special-interest political influence.

At the same time they ramped up investing in politics, to eradicate any environmental wing in the Republican Party (such as the Chafees of Rhode Island). This power exploded when Citizens United let them offer party leaders unlimited secret “dark money.”

Knowing they had no credibility, they set up or took over a legion of front groups, to propagate their message from behind the cover of bland or familiar-sounding names. The front groups numbered in the dozens, like keys on a disinformation piano.

The science was clear. Even Exxon’s scientists knew. The predictions have proven deadly accurate. But when science encounters politics in Congress, politics wins, so fossil fuel went to work to corrupt Congress, deny the science, and mislead the public.

This all began years ago, when a bunch of fossil fuel billionaires saw trouble ahead for their pollution and their pollute-for-free business model, so they began a covert operation to bring industry influence to bear on U.S. politics. Climate denial was born.

Take away those safeguards, and the cracks that result in the integrity of agency proceedings can spread far and wide. If you’re working for big polluter donors (yes, you, Russell Vought) this is a feature not a bug.
Protecting against that obvious possibility, and protecting due process rights of contesting parties in agencies, is a decision Congress has — and should have — the power to make.

Plus, these agencies often handle “contested cases,” often with the government a party. Due process entitles participants to an independent decider in those contested cases. If the White House can fire at will the decision-makers, it can influence the decisions.

Allowing the White House, without intermediation, to regulate energy costs or set corporate reporting requirements or monetary policy is an invitation to abuse and corruption. Congress has — and should have — the power to protect us from that abuse.

Why does this matter? It matters because Congress makes the laws, and should be able to decide when agencies like FERC, SEC, Fed. and others should be independent, not political tools of the President.

A Supreme Court violating foundational principles of rule of law to prevent fact-finding and protect internal misconduct (and perhaps lawbreaking) is a grim set of facts.
The Supreme Court, and now the Judicial Conference, have just seen to it that Thomas is protected even from fact-finding. No one else in government anywhere is so favored.
A foundational principle of rule of law, usually too foundational to require mention, is to find out what the facts are.

At issue here are well-predicated allegations of a Supreme Court Justice violating ethics laws, filing false statements (a possible felony), and committing criminal tax evasion; allegations that have never even been investigated.

The logical through-line here is a sense of “enough is enough” and Thomas should not have to make more disclosures or be investigated properly, and we’ll do whatever legal contortions get that result. But this is actually a big thing to sweep under the rug.
Plus, Thomas’s promise not to break the law going forward has nothing to do with whether Thomas’s past violations might have been willful. That is what the law requires the Conference to focus on.

Next, the Conference says nothing to see here because Thomas fixed errors from past 6 years that aren’t covered by 2023 guidance and promised to do better. But Thomas probably hasn’t even disclosed all of those gifts either (see meals, lodging, football tickets).
https://t.co/RA33KwnlxX

Add that the “guidance” responded to requests for referral about Thomas willfully cheating on his disclosures. It was more an investigation and determination, not a general rulemaking, which would more logically be prospective.

Add forgiveness of his $267,000 motorcoach loan, which has nothing to do with “personal hospitality. That is, under both tax and disclosure laws, income that must be disclosed/declared and taxes paid. Not “personal hospitality”; nothing “new” here; so why no mention of it?

Plus, the Conference had earlier called its guidance a “clarification,” a term with the usual legal inference that it was always thus, and therefore applied to past disclosure filings. That’s why Thomas’s lawyers were so quick to call it a “new rule,” to dodge that inference.

You don’t have to be much of a lawyer to know that transportation is different from “food, lodging, and entertainment,” so there is no question here of complicated, abstruse legal nitpickery. This is plain meaning stuff.

But the 2023 guidance update only made clear what everyone already knew: transportation was never exempted from disclosure, unlike personal hospitality in the form of food, lodging, and entertainment. So there wasn’t much new in the guidance, at least as to transportation.

First, they say, new guidance is usually not retroactive. So the Conference’s 2023 guidance update to crack down on the “personal hospitality” trick that Scalia pioneered doesn’t require Thomas or anyone else to amend prior filings to come into compliance.

As to Thomas’s violations, begin with what the Conference said: judges have to amend filings going back six years when they’ve been submitting false filings. Is Thomas directed to amend back six years? No. Let’s see why not.

The Conference referral notifies DOJ of possible law-breaking. It doesn’t punish justices, so no problem there. But the Conference says it will study this issue. What happens if they realize they can refer justices? Do they reopen the Thomas investigation? They don’t say.
Plus, Congress can regulate administrative tasks like disclosures (as we do for executive), so there’s no separation of powers problem.
The referral is in the “checks and balances” vein, to make sure one branch of government cannot cover up internal misconduct. It makes perfect constitutional sense.

Where does the referral requirement come from? It is federal law, from a statute passed many years ago by Congress and signed into law by the President, and never until now challenged by the Judicial Conference. https://t.co/ifomLHcLJI
